The BEIT (Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation) project has conducted extensive stakeholder engagement with over 20 local experts in Mosul's solar, insulation, and architectural sectors. Pedagogical Pillars of the BEIT Solar Training

Flipped & Active: No sitting back. Participants learn by doing, designing, troubleshooting, and explaining.

Definition: Recognizing solar, insulation, and architecture as interconnected components of one integrated system rather than separate technical domains.

1. Executive Summary
The BEIT (Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation) project has conducted extensive stakeholder engagement with over 20 local experts in Mosul's solar, insulation, and architectural sectors. This engagement revealed a fundamental insight: successful technical training requires more than skills transfer—it demands building communities of practice that connect directly to market needs.

Our stakeholder interviews have transformed our approach from a conventional training model to an ecosystem-building strategy that:

Frames the unique angle of the short modules as "sales engineering" capabilities that combine technical knowledge with understanding client needs
Reframes training as community formation rather than content delivery
Integrates market actors directly into the classroom through employer-judged projects
Creates tangible pathways to employment through internships and real-world projects
Reconnects modern sustainability practices with Iraqi heritage and traditional wisdom

This report documents our engagement process, synthesizes key insights, and presents a framework for implementing training modules that reflect these principles. By centering local expertise and market realities, we aim to create not just skilled technicians, but empowered problem-solvers who can drive Mosul's sustainable reconstruction.
1. Define the Foundational Pedagogy
Let’s summarize and explicitly name the pedagogy we’re using. Based on your insights and interviews:
Pedagogical Pillars of the BEIT Solar Training
Facilitation over Teaching: Trainers are not the source of knowledge—they hold space, provoke inquiry, and support peer-led learning.


Authentic Learning Tasks: Real-world scenarios (like designing your cousin’s system) deepen motivation and skill.


Flipped & Active: No sitting back. Participants learn by doing, designing, troubleshooting, and explaining.


High Standards with High Empathy: Great installs require pride, care, and attention. These are values we model and cultivate.


Mindset Shifts Matter: Confidence, problem-solving, humility, and customer empathy are as critical as wiring know-how.


Minimal Viable Complexity: Start with small, simple installs (like 150 sq ft), then teach how to scale and adapt.


Let’s call this approach something evocative—perhaps the "Apprentice-to-Entrepreneur Pathway" or "Crafted Learning"?

2. Market Development Strategies Section
Based on our interviews and analysis, I've identified key market development strategies that emerged from stakeholder insights. These have been organized in a quadrant chart that evaluates each strategy based on implementation timeline (short vs. long term) and potential impact (moderate vs. high).
Priority Strategies (Short-Term, High Impact)
Solar Festival & Exhibition (SM-HV-8)
Description: Industry showcase event connecting graduates directly with 10-15 solar companies in Mosul
Implementation: Schedule 2-4 weeks after course completion at Mosul Space; each trainee presents their portfolio
Benefits: Immediate job connections, public awareness of solar solutions, community building
Employer-Judged Capstone Competition (SM-HV-7)
Description: Installation competition judged by potential employers to identify talent
Implementation: Day 6 competition with timed installation and quality checks; employers as judges
Benefits: Real demonstration of skills, immediate employment opportunity, standardized assessment
Consignment Stock Program (MW-HV-15)
Description: Equipment suppliers offer components on credit, to be paid after customer installation
Implementation: Formal agreements with suppliers; credential verification; payment tracking system
Benefits: Reduces capital barrier for new entrepreneurs; creates supplier loyalty; enables quick start


RENAC Certification Alignment Recommendations (MH-HV-6)
Description: Formal recognition of training through international certification body
Implementation: Align curriculum with RENAC requirements; co-branded certificates - trainers have official certification and permission to use the logo
Benefits: International recognition; quality assurance; higher value perception
Solar Water Heater Fast-Track (DN-HV-14)
Description: Lower-cost entry point to solar market through 3-day specialized program
Implementation: Condensed curriculum; target plumbers and general contractors
Benefits: Market diversification; lower entry barrier; complementary to PV market
Support & Specialization (Long-Term, Moderate Impact)
Alumni Support Network (Multiple)
Description: Community of practice for graduates to share leads, troubleshooting, and opportunities
Implementation: WhatsApp group; quarterly meet-ups; job posting channel
Benefits: Continuous learning; professional development; business referrals

3. Community as Curriculum
Definition: The training approach shifts from passive knowledge transfer to actively building a supportive community of practice that sustains beyond the formal training period.
Key Stakeholder Insights:
"We realized that we didn't want the training to be a transfer of material, but rather a community being formed. We got that from hearing about some of the people that went through these other training programs and how they continue to support each other until this day." - Bilal's reflection
"At the end of each day, I ask one question... each person [answers] on a small sticker." - Muayad Hasan (MH-HV-13)
"The best thing... I have them... each one chooses a topic [to teach]." - Hussam Falih (HF-HV-16)
Practical Implementation:
Daily Reflection Circles: End each training day with Muayad's sticky note method where participants anonymously share one thing they learned, found interesting, or still find unclear.
Peer Teaching Assignments: Following Hussam's approach, assign each trainee a component or concept to teach back to the group using simple language and visual aids.
Mixed Rotation Groups: Create diverse small groups that change throughout the program, ensuring trainees build relationships across the cohort.
WhatsApp Alumni Group: Establish digital community spaces where graduates can continue sharing job opportunities, technical questions, and success stories.
Connection to Employment:
This community-building approach creates a supportive network that facilitates job referrals, technical troubleshooting assistance, and business partnerships long after the formal training ends. The 30 RENAC graduates from 2019 who "all still work together" (DN-HV-6) exemplify this success.
4. Empathy-Driven Sales Engineering
Definition: Repositioning technical specialists as problem-solvers who align solutions with client needs rather than simply pushing products.
Key Stakeholder Insights:
"We had a big idea to get people to be more interactive and start to move into a sales engineering focus, to combine the financial literacy element with the elements that we've been working on through sales engineering." - Bilal's reflection
"The most important thing is that this coffee machine works for me." - Mustafa Waleed recounting a client's priority (MW)
"If your room is not 10 degrees cooler in three weeks after you install... then you don't pay for the install." - Bilal quoting an installation company's guarantee
"We must run the numbers so people see why the 'expensive' one is actually cheaper." - Ali Abkan (AA-HV-3)
Practical Implementation:
Client Needs Assessment: Train participants to begin every client interaction with questions about priorities and pain points rather than immediately proposing technical solutions.
ROI Calculation Templates: Provide customizable spreadsheets showing lifetime cost comparisons between different quality tiers and system configurations.
Role-Play Sales Scenarios: Practice responding to common client objections and concerns with evidence-based, empathetic responses.
Success Story Bank: Compile local case studies demonstrating how proper need assessment led to more satisfied customers and appropriate system sizing.
Connection to Employment:
This approach differentiates graduates in the marketplace as consultative sellers rather than mere technicians. Companies value sales engineers who can accurately scope projects, manage customer expectations, and close deals based on value rather than competing solely on price.
5. Environment as Teacher
Definition: Using local environmental conditions as primary design factors and teaching tools rather than relying solely on theoretical scenarios.
Key Stakeholder Insights:
"Dust neglect is the top performance killer." - Hussam Falih (HF-HV-20)
"Battery location/heat is top Mosul failure." - Mustafa Waleed (MW-HV-3)
"Solar panels provide a little bit of shading from the sun, insulation, and because of that they are going to cool the room down below them." - Bilal's reflection
"Wind-loaded roofs snap because pavers on sand aren't structural." - Muayad Hasan (MH-Qual-1)
Practical Implementation:
Local Condition Documentation: Create a comprehensive guide to Mosul-specific environmental challenges (dust, heat, grid instability, wind loads) with photographic examples.
Live Demonstrations: Show power production differences between clean and dusty panels; measure temperature variations in well-ventilated versus confined battery locations.
Site Visit Checklists: Develop detailed assessment forms that prioritize environmental factors specific to Mosul.
Failure Photos Library: Compile a visual library of real installation failures caused by environmental factors for use in troubleshooting exercises.
Connection to Employment:
Graduates with this environment-focused training will design more resilient systems with longer lifespans, fewer maintenance issues, and better performance—creating higher customer satisfaction and more referrals. This approach also builds critical thinking skills rather than reliance on generic design templates.
6. Interdependency of Modules
Definition: Recognizing solar, insulation, and architecture as interconnected components of one integrated system rather than separate technical domains.
Key Stakeholder Insights:
"If a roof is insulated, you need fewer panels. If a window is reoriented, you reduce heating/cooling costs. Each insight compounds—students can model the cascade effect." - Bilal's reflection
"You might, with a little bit of changes, really create a step-level change in the cost of a panel install, and so if you encourage someone to take their hot water heater or maybe one of their fridges...off of the solar battery, then you can actually reduce maybe a battery pack to panels, and really reduce the cost a lot." - Bilal quoting a trainer
"Window orientation = winter illness... these are the invisible costs we must surface." - Excerpt from report notes
Practical Implementation:
Cross-Module Simulation: Create calculation exercises demonstrating how improvements in one domain reduce requirements in others (e.g., insulation reducing solar system size).
Integrated Design Challenges: Assign projects requiring trainees to consider all three domains simultaneously when developing solutions.
Shared Terminology: Develop a common glossary of terms across all modules to reinforce interdisciplinary thinking.
Combined Site Assessments: Practice evaluating buildings holistically for solar potential, insulation needs, and architectural modifications simultaneously.
Connection to Employment:
Graduates with this integrated perspective can offer more comprehensive solutions, identify opportunities for cost savings across domains, and provide better value to clients. This approach also creates natural referral pathways between specialists in different fields.
7. Seeing Beyond the System
Definition: Identifying and communicating non-obvious benefits beyond direct energy savings, including comfort, health, property value, and equipment lifespan.
Key Stakeholder Insights:
"Even if having your insulation doesn't mean you will never use the air conditioning, but if it reduces the number of days a year, hours a year, that it's operating, your air conditioning unit will last longer." - Bilal's reflection
"When you sell a house with solar, the price will be extra." - Hussam Falih (quote from notes)
"It's not just the idea of things being cheaper. What happens is it's actually also a way to get just better air." - Bilal's reflection
"It makes a difference in who gets colds and who doesn't get colds." - Bilal quoting architecture expert on window orientation
Practical Implementation:
Comprehensive Benefit Analysis: Create templates that calculate not just energy savings but also extended equipment life, health improvements, and property value increases.
Storytelling Frameworks: Develop story structures that help trainees articulate these benefits to clients through relatable examples.
Long-term ROI Calculators: Provide tools that factor in these additional benefits to show true lifetime value.
Quality of Life Assessment: Train participants to discuss comfort and health impacts with clients as key decision factors.
Connection to Employment:
This approach enables graduates to differentiate themselves by selling value rather than just technical specifications. It also helps overcome price objections by quantifying benefits that might otherwise be overlooked in basic payback calculations.
8. Real-World Capstone Projects
Definition: Using authentic client scenarios, real sites, and employer assessment to bridge the gap between training and employment.
Key Stakeholder Insights:
"The suggestion emerged to not attempt at having a sort of documented way to show people having new skills and having it on paper, but to find ways of practically and tangibly demonstrating those skills directly in front of potential employers and potential customers." - Bilal's reflection
"The exam is the interview with a company." - Mohammed Al-Qatan (MQ-HV-6)
"Competition day = fast install with zero errors; winners hired." - Saud Maan (SM-HV-7)
"We can make a solar festival." - Saud Maan (SM-HV-8)
Practical Implementation:
Employer Judging Panel: Invite local solar companies to evaluate trainee capstone projects using standardized rubrics.
Real Client Designs: Assign trainees to develop complete proposals for their own homes or those of family members.
Installation Competition: Structure Day 6 as a timed installation challenge with quality checks by potential employers.
Post-Program Solar Festival: Organize an industry showcase 2-4 weeks after course completion where graduates can present portfolios.
Connection to Employment:
This approach creates immediate employment pathways by allowing companies to observe skills firsthand rather than relying on certificates. The competition format also helps identify standout performers while the client-based projects ensure graduates can handle real-world scenarios.
